text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Sunday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The newly-formed Sindh province coalition government faced a serious set-back when four of its ministers told the chief minister they planned to resign.
- The government has banned lavish meals, fireworks and illuminations at weddings and allowed serving of hot or cold drinks only.
- Pakistan, as a goodwill gesture, has announced it will release 38 Indian children who were apprehended on boats trespassing into Pakistan's territorial waters.
- Pakistani embassies worldwide have been told not to issue visas until March 28 in a security precaution for the upcoming Islamic summit in Islamabad, official sources said.
- Top bankers have urged Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz to help the state-run banks and financial institutions to curb unscrupulous trade union activities.

- High Commissioner of Australia Geoffrey Allen said an air service agreement was being negotiated with Pakistan to open new vistas for economic relations between the two countries. - The sowing of wheat in comparison to other crops has become less profitable for growers leading to a considerable decline in wheat cultivation, official APP news agency said.
- With the borrowing rate at 22 percent, Pakistani industry has become uncompetitive and the financial sector has to play a vital role to reduce the cost of production, Sartaj Aziz said.
- Sartaj Aziz said that $55 million had been collected in Prime Minister's Debt Retirement Programme and pledges for another $75 million had been made so far.
- Japan and Pakistan will sign the final loan agreement on March 31 for the disbursement of $250 million to Pakistan, under the 31st yen loan package.
- A net fall of 37 percent in the collection of land and other revenue of Punjab province was apparent during the first six months of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June).

- Saima Waheed, a 22-year-old Pakistani woman who went missing a few days after winning an 11-month court battle against her father's challenge to her love marriage, has appeared in a state-run shelter in Rawalpindi.
- After completion of technical work by the International Monetary Fund team, Pakistan and the IMF start their formal discussions on Tuesday.
- Prominent jurist and former judge of the Supreme Court, Dorab Patel died on Saturday after protracted illness.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has directed government departments to prepare lists of corrupt officials.
